verse_commentaries.commentary: Superscription introduces unusual term בִּנְגִינוֹת (bin-gi-NOT) - literally 'with stringed instruments' from root נגן. This specifies instrumental accompaniment, distinguishing this psalm from others. The Davidic attribution links to royal psalmic tradition. LXX translates with generic 'in psalms' (ἐν ψαλμός), showing interpretive flexibility about performance context.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Establishes temple/liturgical setting mentioned in thesis, though independent interest in ancient Israelite musical practice

verse_commentaries.commentary: Opens with temporal clause בְּקׇרְאִי (be-qa-REE) 'when I call' - sets conditional frame. Epithet אֱלֹהֵי צִדְקִ֗י (e-lo-HEI tsid-QI) is grammatically ambiguous: 'God of my righteousness' or 'God my vindicator'? Spatial metaphor בַּצָּר הִרְחַבְתָּ (ba-TSAR hir-KHAV-ta) literally 'in narrow-place you-made-wide' - movement from constriction to freedom. Four imperatives create urgency: עֲנֵנִי חׇנֵּנִי שְׁמַע (answer, have-mercy, hear).
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Establishes petition-based-on-past-deliverance pattern from thesis; spatial metaphor becomes key theological frame

verse_commentaries.commentary: Direct address shifts to בְּנֵי אִישׁ (be-NEI ish) - literally 'sons of man' but may denote social class ('men of rank'). Rhetorical question עַד־מֶה (ad-MEH) 'until when?' expresses exasperation. Three parallel verbs targeting opponents' pursuits: תֶּאֱהָבוּן רִיק תְּבַקְשׁוּ כָזָב (love emptiness, seek falsehood). Term כְבוֹדִי לִכְלִמָּה (ke-vo-DI lich-lim-MAH) 'my glory to shame' - what is this 'glory'? Personal honor, divine reflection, reputation?
figurative_analysis: emptiness and falsehood as objects of pursuit
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Confirms opponents-seeking-false-security theme from thesis, but 'glory' language deserves independent exploration beyond thesis framework

verse_commentaries.commentary: Imperative וּדְעוּ (u-de-U) 'and know!' introduces epistemological claim. Verb הִפְלָה (hif-LAH) is semantically rich: 'set apart,' 'distinguish,' 'make wonderful' - from root פלא (wonder/miracle). Term חָסִיד (kha-SID) 'faithful/pious one' is covenant vocabulary. Double use of יְהֹוָה creates anaphoric emphasis. Final clause בְּקׇרְאִ֥י אֵלָֽיו (be-qa-REE e-LAV) 'when-I-call to-Him' creates inclusio with v2's opening.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Supports thesis's emphasis on YHWH's attentiveness and election theology, though הִפְלָה's semantic range extends beyond thesis discussion

verse_commentaries.commentary: Verb רִגְזוּ (rig-ZU) is interpretively contested: 'tremble,' 'be angry,' 'be agitated'? Followed immediately by אַל־תֶּחֱטָאוּ (al-tekh-TA-u) 'do not sin' - creates sequence (tremble THEN don't sin, or tremble SO THAT you don't sin?). Commands shift to introspection: אִמְרוּ בִלְבַבְכֶם (im-RU vil-vav-KHEM) 'speak in your hearts' and עַל־מִשְׁכַּבְכֶם (al-mish-kav-KHEM) 'on your beds' - evening context emerges. Final imperative וְדֹמּוּ (ve-DOM-mu) 'be silent' from root דמם.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Evening context critical to thesis's 'sleep as theological test' argument; introspective commands support instruction-to-opponents framework

verse_commentaries.commentary: Imperative זִבְחוּ זִבְחֵי־צֶדֶק (ziv-KHU ziv-khei-TSE-deq) uses cognate accusative construction: 'sacrifice sacrifices-of-righteousness' - intensifies meaning. What are 'sacrifices of righteousness'? Ethical prerequisite? Right ritual? The צֶדֶק root links back to v2's אֱלֹהֵי צִדְקִי creating lexical cohesion. Final imperative וּבִטְחוּ אֶל־יְהֹוָה (u-vit-KHU el-yah-WEH) 'and trust in YHWH' - trust as culminating command.
figurative_analysis: sacrifice as metaphor for right relationship?
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Connects to thesis's mention of 'sacrifices in righteousness' as proper worship response; צֶדֶק inclusio strengthens structural argument

verse_commentaries.commentary: Sudden shift to quoted speech: רַבִּים אֹמְרִים (ra-BIM om-RIM) 'many are saying' - voices skeptics. Their question מִי־יַרְאֵנוּ טוֹב (mi-yar-E-nu tov) 'who will show us good?' reveals epistemological crisis at psalm's heart. Psalmist's response/prayer נְסָה־עָלֵינוּ אוֹר פָּנֶיךָ (ne-SAH a-LEI-nu or pa-NEI-kha) 'lift upon us light of your face' - priestly blessing language (Num 6:25). The 'face of God' motif is theologically loaded.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Central to thesis's epistemological crisis argument: what IS 'good' and how do we obtain it? Aaronic blessing connection strengthens liturgical context claim

verse_commentaries.commentary: Perfect verb נָתַתָּה שִׂמְחָה (na-TAT-ta sim-KHAH) 'you have given joy' - psalmist's counter-testimony to v7's skeptics. Temporal phrase מֵעֵת (me-ET) is ambiguous: 'from the time when' or 'more than the time when'? Opponents have דְּגָנָם וְתִירוֹשָׁם (de-ga-NAM ve-ti-ro-SHAM) 'their grain and their wine' - covenant blessing vocabulary (Deut 7:13, Hos 2:8-9). Verb רָבּוּ (RAB-bu) 'they multiplied/increased' shows material abundance. The comparison structure is crucial: divine joy vs. material prosperity.
figurative_analysis: agricultural abundance as measure of well-being
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Core of thesis's comparative theology argument: material abundance doesn't correlate with well-being; supports 'competing securities' framework

verse_commentaries.commentary: Triple rest vocabulary: אֶשְׁכְּבָה (esh-ke-VAH) 'I lie down,' וְאִישָׁן (ve-I-shan) 'and I sleep,' בְּשָׁלוֹם (be-sha-LOM) 'in peace/safety.' The יַחְדָּו (yakh-DAV) 'together/at once' is curious - simultaneously? The emphatic לְבָדָד (le-va-DAD) 'alone' is syntactically ambiguous: modifies 'You LORD' or 'me'? Final verb תּוֹשִׁיבֵנִי (to-shi-VEI-ni) 'you make me dwell' from ישב (settle/dwell) with לָבֶטַח (la-VE-takh) 'in security.' Entire verse creates closure with v2's spatial liberation.
verse_commentaries.thesis_connection: Climax of thesis's 'sleep as theological validation' argument; לְבָדָד supports monotheistic/monolatrous trust claim; inclusio with v2 confirms structural analysis

thematic_threads: Rhetorical progression: petition (v2) → accusation (v3) → declaration (v4) → instruction (vv5-6) → contrast (vv7-8) → testimony (v9) - psalmist assumes multiple roles
Evening/night motif intensifies: implicit in v2's distress, explicit in v5's 'bed,' climactic in v9's 'lie down and sleep' - creates liturgical and metaphorical frame
צֶדֶק root creates inclusio: v2 אֱלֹהֵי צִדְקִי and v6 זִבְחֵי־צֶדֶק - righteousness/vindication frames the psalm's theological argument
Imperative density concentrated in vv5-6 (seven commands) - psalmist claims teaching authority despite being mocked
Spatial metaphors progress: v2 narrow→wide; v9 dwelling securely - movement from constriction to secure habitation
Divine name pattern: אֱלֹהִים (v2) shifts to יְהֹוָה (vv4,6,7,9) - generic to covenantal specificity
Comparison structure pervades: v3 glory vs. shame, emptiness vs. substance; v7-8 skeptics' question vs. psalmist's testimony; v8 divine joy vs. material abundance
interesting_questions: What is the precise semantic range of הִפְלָה in v4 - does it emphasize divine election, miraculous intervention, or distinction/separation, and how does each reading alter the theology?
How should רִגְזוּ in v5 be translated - 'tremble' (in religious awe), 'be angry' (moral indignation), or 'be agitated' (anxiety) - and how does this affect the logical connection to 'sin no more'?
Is the לְבָדָד in v9 syntactically attached to 'You LORD alone' (monotheistic emphasis) or to 'me dwelling alone in security' (psychological self-sufficiency through God)?
What exactly are זִבְחֵי־צֶדֶק ('sacrifices of righteousness') in v6 - ethically correct sacrifices, sacrifices offered by the righteous, or sacrifices that produce righteousness?
Does the temporal/comparative מֵעֵת in v8 mean 'from/since the time when' (temporal simultaneity) or 'more than' (quantitative superiority), and how does this affect the comparison?
What is the significance of בְּנֵי אִישׁ in v3 - generic 'mortals,' or social class 'men of rank/nobility' - and how does this identification affect the conflict's nature?
How does כָבוֹד ('glory') in v3 function - is this personal reputation/honor, divine glory reflected in the righteous, or a technical theological term?
What does the יַחְדָּו ('together/at once') contribute in v9 - are lying down and sleeping unified as single restful action, or does it suggest something else?
Is the טוֹב ('good') in v7 material prosperity, ethical goodness, or existential well-being - and does this align with deuteronomic blessing theology or subvert it?
How does the spatial metaphor בַּצָּר הִרְחַבְתָּ (narrow→wide) in v2 function - architectural, geographical, psychological, or legal (siege, landscape, anxiety, confinement)?
Why does the LXX add 'oil' to the grain-and-wine formula in v8, creating the full covenant blessing triad?
What is the relationship between introspective commands in v5 (speak in heart, ponder on bed, be silent) and ritual command in v6 (offer sacrifices) - repentance process or proper worship sequence?
synthesis_notes:
LEXICON: Investigate הִפְלָה semantic range (election vs. miracle vs. distinction); רִגְזוּ contested meanings; לְבָדָד syntactic attachments; מֵעֵת temporal vs. comparative uses
CONCORDANCE: Track צֶדֶק root uses creating inclusio; אוֹר פָּנֶיךָ connections to Aaronic blessing; דָגָן וְתִירוֹשׁ covenant blessing formula occurrences; spatial narrow→wide metaphors
FIGURATIVE: Bed/sleep imagery as theological metaphor (vv5,9); glory/shame binary (v3); face-light symbolism (v7); dwelling/security language (v9)
COMMENTARY: V4 election theology; v5 introspection sequence; v6 sacrifice terminology; v7 epistemological crisis; v8 comparative structure; v9 syntactic ambiguities
INTERTEXTUAL: Numbers 6:25 Aaronic blessing (v7); Ephesians 4:26 NT citation of v5; Deuteronomy 7:13 grain-wine blessing formula (v8); Psalm 3 sleep/enemy parallels
